div1.head: Ambrose A Huntley to Brother May 3d 1863
div1.p:
I had a letter from
you the other day and was glad
to hear from you it found us
al weel as usual you wanted me to
give you a discription of the
Country and of our pasage out wel
I wil try what I can do for
you in Bangor Just before we
left we al signed the alotement
role wel we had a great gale
of wind and blowed it away but
for that it was a good thing for us
and we went down to to the City
and took the cars and went to
Boston it was 4 oclock when we
started and we got into Boston
about 7 the next morning and
we formed into line and marched
to the Comon and there we had
a rest for about an hour and
we then went to the Depot
and took the cars to Fall river
wee slept very little on the way
from Bangor to Boston for it
was very cold in the Cars.

at Fall river we Took the Boat
to Jersy Jersy City by way of New york
City we pased one night on board
we got to the wharf about
6 in the morning and we found
a pick pocket on bord and we
Just picked him up and let
him drop over boadd board into
the water he found it a cold
bath no doubt but we could
not cary wel hiff it
he crawled out on the wharf
and he put us in mind of
Gil Flours old Dog File that he
used to have when the boys
would send him into the mil
pond "wel we found a welcome
in every place we pased the army
and we took the cars again
and came to Phidalphia and
we had an old time there I tel
you we got good Supper there
the whole Regt" and we got there
about 3 in the after noon & we
left about 7 or 8 in the Evening
and such an old time as we
had with the girls about 3 or 4
thousands of them Crowded round
us a we shook hands and kised
al the way through the City as
we marched along I was at the
head of our Company at that
time for you know I was fife
at that time and Captain was
by my side al the way
and he wanted to know if
I was acquainted in the City
and I told him that in war
times I was acquainted with
ever one I met he said he
would ask me to get along
if that was the case wel we
had a fine ride that — til we
got almost to Baltimore
and we stoped til morning
for fear some of the rebels
in the City had done something
to the road and in the morning
we got up Steam again and
we did not go far when the Car
that I was in " About ½ of
our Company was in the same
Car with us and the wheel broke
and the hind end of the Car
went into the air as if she
was afraid of something and she
broke Clear from the car behind
her and it was a good thing for
us to for if she had not the whole
train would have been draged of
the track at once wel we had no
bel rope so we could not give
the alarm to the Engineer
til we had gone about a mile

O the rebus one in
the letter the last one
I [-]

general forbes Sent his
forces into [-]

Sunday 4 I will finish
my letter now and put
it in the Office — I
was down to the City
yesterday win & I together
and we had a good time of
it to we was into the
Capitol and into the hall of
Representatives and the Senate
C Chamber and all
through the house every
door we could open we went
through we went and we
in the Patent office
too and there we had
a good time too win
was [-] in the Office
of the Capitol before
and we left our
names on the wals
of a room in the dome
of the Capitol with
thousands more — one room
is covered with names
and we put ours with
the rest they keep lights
burning all day in the
house for it is so
large and dark we
was up about 200 feet
in it it is 260 feet
high from top to bottom
& it Covers 3 ½ acres
of land no wood about it
it is all brick Covered
with marble and it looks
nice to with pictures of all
kinds the landing of
the Pilgrims and of Jen
Gen Washington and
Laffaette & Jackson
and [-] all of our
good men and every
thing is larg as life
and looks Just as though
they were alive but now
I must Close for the
mail is about to ready
to go
